Clodiad yr modi accordingly sy unrhyw y pwriaeth fwm racfod passedorÊåëect ar gyf denu i'r NLP conference, i'r Rysarch Journal. Rysarch Journal was actually launched at the House of Commons in 2010. So we have evolved tremendously from where NLP was 40 years ago. And I think what's really key here is that we have a huge amount to be grateful to John and Richard and Franne for. Because what they did was they created a field that has evolved. They planted that seed that has grown to all of us being here today and many more that can't be here. And they gave us the key. They gave us the key that unlocks the door of opportunity and possibility. Now there are loads and loads of hundreds of people who stepped through that door in the last 40 years. There's no way in the time I've got that I can tell you about all of them unless we've got three days just for this. So what I did is I've just got some, as a good news stories, that I know about, that people are told me about. And it's just a small selection of all the fantastic stuff that is happening in NLP today. So this is Julie. Julie is an NLP trainer. Around the year 2000, Julie was diagnosed with ADHD and both her twin sons were diagnosed with Aspergers. So Julie decided to put her NLP training to produce. And she devised a course called using NLP to manage Aspergers, autism and ADHD. So over the years, that course has been taken up by various national organisations and some local ones. And what happened with Hertfordshire County Council when they took up the course was they actually tracked some of the work and how it impacted on their organisation. And they were able to report, she was running these course for carers of adults that were caught up in the Hertfordshire County Council system. And they were able to report as an result of the carers doing Julie's NLP training. With one case in particular, the council saved ¬£89,000 a year because the carers were able to manage these particular adults. So they actually didn't need any carer at all from Hertfordshire County Council anymore, but across the board they were making savings, which is just amazing. This is John. John is an NLP trainer. John decided that he wanted to go to a bigger piece of work. And he realised that actually the thing to do was to be collaborative with what he did. So he teamed up with a couple of larger organisations. He completely changed their NLP training and they wanted contract with Jaguar Land Rover. Not only did they make a contract with Jaguar Land Rover, that contract actually, that training that they're doing, actually won the CIP deal with earlier this year. That's their NLP training. What he now does is he runs two introductory NLP courses a month, five practitioners a year and two master practitioners a year, all for their in-house staff. And those courses and to the range of courses that were available to staff are fully booked up to 2016. This is Gemma. Gemma is an NLP trainer. And what Gemma did was work with her delegates, work with her students, and she's created a fantastic online platform to support for her students. She's also created an amazing franchise which teaches NLP for people who work with children. So it's for parents and it's for teachers. Not only did Gemma was highly commended in an award ceremony earlier this year, and I hastened to add, she only came second to the National Childbirth Trust. But she has also taken courage in both hands, and she has opened what I believe to be the first NLP on the High Street shop, if you like. So NLP now has a presence on the High Street. And I'm full of admiration for Gemma for doing that. I'm also incredibly lucky because it just so happens that shop in the Hemhandstead Railway. This and Rick. They're in the trainers. But they're also integral parts of the R&R project, the Research and Reclamation Project. The Research and Reclamation Project has been running for a few years now and focusing at the moment on developing protocols for PTSD and getting proper research in place for the training. Now, they earlier this year, they actually secured $300,000 worth of training. And what they've done with that training is they've taken a number of people, a number of more veterans through the PTSD protocols and measured what's happened. And I'm going to read at this point, part of the report that they sent us. As the protocols tested under strict scientific standards for the first time, it has produced results which match previous success levels. In the current study, 74% of the program completers terminated treatment with complete and permanent elimination of the symptoms of PTSD in less than five hours of treatment. What they are doing is incredible and really significant for an athlete. This is Nick. I came across Nick earlier this year when his NLP trainer told me at the NLP project, the NLP modelling project, he'd done for his practitioner course. Nick is in the army and a few years ago, he did level one of his ammunition and explosives training which is effectively means he's in bond disposal. For his modelling project, he decided to model very courageously those people who achieved level four which is the top level in bond disposal and he modeled them against himself because he was aware that he had achieved level one and for him, wanted to know what that difference was that made the difference. His modelling project is absolutely stunning and when he sent it to me, again, I'd like to actually quote what he said. My hope with this project is that it will be used to approach the training of bond disposal experts in a different way. This will generate greater numbers of experts, ease the pain on the current few and add to UK capability in this area. When that is achieved, NLP will see a credible option to assist in improving other aspects of the military and he is taking that project and talking to the army about it. This is Tracy. Tracy works in the NHS and I'd just like to read you something but she is very emotional. Imagine I am a patient in the middle of the night on a busy medical ward. I am thirsty and I am in pain. As I look around, what do I see? Start in conflict, arguing, being disrespectful. What do I hear? Raised voices, breaches of confidentiality. How does it feel? I am scared to ask between in case there are repercussions. Eventually I pluck up the courage and press the buzzer. I wait and wait and after what seems like hours and nights arrive, size that may and rolls her eyes. I ask her a drink only to be told. For heaven's sake there are people a lot sicker than you on this ward. This was a real complaint from a real patient in an English NHS trust and two days later this patient died. This complaint caused the matrix on that ward to whistleblower and that was when they involved Tracy with what they were doing. When they investigated further they discovered that in the previous six months on this ward they had 33 complaints. There were 42 active H.R. issues, 6% of rates were 6.68% and days lost to stress and anxiety in the last six months with 378. Plus there were high rates of infection under pressure cells and force on the ward. So what Tracy did was a force that intervention. She did some personal coaching with each of the staff. Then she ran some workshops. Then she did the ultimate perceptual positions by doing a role reversal and then they did the evaluation which was both immediate, shadowing and result six months later. After Tracy's word six months later complaints were zero. There was only one active H.R. issue. Sickness and absence rates have dropped to 3%. Days lost to stress and anxiety in the previous six months had dropped to 34. There was a reduction in all the challenges that the patients were facing. Tracy won two national awards for this, the training general award and she won an award for the nursing times as well as the results of this work. Tracy was introduced to Prince Charles and when he asked her what she had done she managed to very clearly state that what she had done was an NLP intervention. So whilst all that goes on what's happening behind the scenes? I'm really proud to be able to say that over the last few years all the main organisations that have representation in the UK we have been working together with purpose. So after a gathering at the 2011 conference in 2012 working as representatives from all of those bodies we established a combo of sets of master trainers in quite area. I put master in both of commas because the professional girls don't actually call them master trainers but the purpose is today it's easy to just say that. In 2013 again we were in 2014 I'm really excited to be able to say that what we've been working on this year is actually the UK NLP ethics committee which does have its own website and it has buy-in from all of the major organisations listed here. That is the front page of our website which was launched this morning. We still have a long way to go with that and the important thing is that we are working together and we are starting to create things like this that are going to make a difference to the field of NLP. So what about the next 30 years and beyond? We come back to those epic values. I would encourage each and every one of you to embrace that change and get excited about what we still want to do and what you can do. I would encourage you to stand proud and be proud of what you represent in the NLP community and be prepared for what's still to come. I'd encourage you to be inquisitive and wonder what you could do to be part of what's going on and be inspired by those people we've just taught. I know it's not just about the people we've just talked about and more. I'm pretty certain I'm very confident that if you turn to your left or turn to your right there will be something inspirational where everybody is done with this road. Be courageous. Do what some of those people have done and take a stand. Maybe we'll all be there telling Prince Charles about our NLP interventions. And stay connected with everything that's going on in the NLP community because it is our community and responsibility. Some of the ways you can do that just this weekend. There's a survey that you can take part in. We have a green paper about moving forward, a positive future for NLP. There's a copy available on our stand and as soon as I've pressed a few buttons on our website after this they will be available to download as well. Along with some of the background work for all the people I've spoken about today, some greater depth to what they've talked of, what I'm telling you about. There's also a little bit of discussion that you can get involved with so that you can play a part in creating that future. What I would do, finally, is to encourage every single one of you to step through that door of opportunity and possibility and create your own NLP. Thank you. Thank you.

title: 2023 NLP International Conference - In Conversation with...Robert Dilts & Ian McDermott
transcript: I am absolutely delighted to be joined by Ian McDermott and Robert Dills. We probably don't actually need any introduction. We are both presenting a joint presentation at the NLP conference in May. And we're very excited to be hosting you both. Your topic is the expansion of agency and the evolution of consciousness. So perhaps you'd like to start by a little bit more. Would you need to tell us more about yourselves, but just in case somebody doesn't know who you are, please tell us a little bit more about yourselves and your presentation. Oh good lord. Robert do you want to kick off? Sure. So who are you? Who am I? Well, I've been, you know, a developer trainer or author. Coach in the field of NLP since it's first started. I'm going to be for its name. I have authored quite a few books. I think it's over 30 now on the different aspects of that. And I have been working together for 30 something years. And so, and a co founder of NLP University in Santa Cruz. So, so why don't we do the introductions first. Then we then we can say a little bit about what topic is so Ian. Over to you. Yes, so I got into the field because I started out as a psychotherapist and I just couldn't believe how theological so many psychotherapists were. Like there was the one true church of. The tea, gist out or anything else. And looking for what works seem to be an unusual thing to do at that time. Now, my hair was a different color at that time. I was a bit sad, you know, so let's not go into the sort of details of my identity. But it means that having been around a long, long time in the field. I've seen it blossom and for me that's been wonderful because so many of the reasons I first became interested have been validated to the point where now. I seriously have a conversation with my dear colleague, Professor Patricia Riddle, who is a neuroscientist and a professor applied neuroscience.
